Kurasu on.... NITONS
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher 2 Archive (PSOne): Monster Types: Niton: Kurasu on.... NITONS
By Kurasu Soratobu on Friday, June 9, 2000 - 09:40 am:

I've heard _so_ much about people disliking Nitons, or no comments about htem at all. Personally, I say what's not to like? They're... uh.... they.... ah.... and... er...

Ok! So Nitons haven't got as much going for them as some of the monsters out there. They're slow, have little skill to speak of (but not as bad as Gaboo, I might like to point out!), and low power, as well. Their attacks aern't powerful, they aren't good at life, and their looks leave something to be desired. So why do I like them so much? Couldn't tell you. But I _can_ tell you their good parts!

Nitons are defense-monsters. They have some of the best defense gains in the game, and a +1 on Swim drills makes this even more 'appetiznig'. They also have _incredible_ withering attacks, right from the get-go. Your Niton isn't going to be much of a K.O. monster, but you'd better bet that it makes a heck of an antagonizer.

Attacks-wise, Nitons have a _lot_ of intelligence attacks. While their intelligence is generally low (for the purebreeds), getting just about any crossbreed will end up giving you an intelligence-gain boost, which in turn will give you more attack-power. Moer 'bang for yuor buck', if you will. The Sonic Attacks are especially nice, since they chain into bigger ones, and they're hit techs, as well as will-draining. The heavy shock is a must-have, too.

Nitons are _not_ a critter for the beginning trainer. They take a lot of patience, a ton of skill, and more than a little heavy work to get what you want. A first generation Niton isn't going to be the critter of choice,either, but once yuo get the second in, or get some other critter bred with it, yuo're giong to fnid that they make for a very good, strong, and HARD TO HURT monster.

By Tony on Saturday, June 10, 2000 - 05:52 am:

Good evaluation, Kurasu. I knew they were tough in DEF, and that was about all I knew about them. What about Guts Regen for them compared to a fast or a slow monster?

By Kurasu Soratobu on Saturday, June 10, 2000 - 10:40 am:

I haven't done actual counting, but their regen is actually pretty good. Nowhere near a pixie or ghost's, but it seems to keep up pretty well with the draining. Of course, I used a Niton/Kato for a lot of my evaluation, so I can't tell you for _certain_. You'd have to watch the Niton the computer plays (as pitiful as he is) to be sure. As I remember, though, it's enough to keep up with some of the better critters.

By Zaid on Tuesday, June 13, 2000 - 04:07 pm:

I've been raising niton breeds for awhile now. One is a niton/kato and the other a niton/durahan.
Yes, nitons have great gains for their defense stats, but their other stats (preferably the offensive ones: pow and int and the more needed skill) are awfully low. Besides, a selketo with very good defense (999) and about 500+ to 600+ on its other stats would have a better chance to be in the HOF. A selketo by the way is a arrowhead/
joker. What I'm driving at is that arrowheads have better techniques and with better hit percentage. Most of the more damaging moves of Nitons have C or D hit percentage. Both my nitons have difficulty raising their skill stats, but through the help of trorons, I've raised them to some good extent. But I'm not yet through with raising them. I'm finishing my raising project on my niton/durahan (both of my nitons have already 999 defense :D ) and later combined it with my niton/kato.

Why do I seem to have patience raising these critters? Well, I like to prove that not all seemingly meak monsters suck in battle and in raising. I want to proove that a good raising style would surely make any monster a very good monster, a bankable one and a hall of famer. I've
been using RNA's technique for awhile, with some of Dark Phoenix's ideas. Good luck for me.
